Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Enabling large-scale manufacturing of organic electronic devices using photolithography
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop a method of
patterning chemically sensitive organic electronic materials using photolithography and other standard cleanroom processes. The technology is based on the development of a fluorous based photoresist. The process to be developed will not damage organic semiconductors, which are destroyed by most organic solvents and water.

The technology will solve many of the problems that plague the organic electronics industry, particularly related to OLED manufacturing. The technology has the potential to enable large scale manufacturing of OLED displays using existing LCD equipment, dramatically lower the cost and improving yields by using proven techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Phase I project focused on creating a commercially viable product for the manufacturing of flexible displays using the installed infrastructure that is used to make LCD TVs. The original technology was developed at Cornell University before being spun out to form Orthogonal, Inc. The materials developed at Cornell were not suited to mass production since they required complicated synthesis that would make the products cost-prohibitive in the competitive display industry.

 

The product was completed successfully, with two cheaper potential products being demonstrated, named Ortho 210 and Ortho 310.  Each of these polymers were made using one or two step synthesis and could be made at high volumes even in the lab environment that Orthogonal had at its disposal. Advances in the processing using these chemicals were improved as well, making the process more compatible with customer equipment.

 

The products have since been shipped to customers for initial testing with positive early results. These customers (that are amongst the largest panel manufacturers in the world) are using these products to pursue applications in flexible eReaders, instead of the initially anticipated application of organic light emitting diode (OLED) manufacturing. Because of this, Orthogonal has changed focus to support this market pull and has found greater demand for its products as a result.

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2012
Modified by: John Defranco
